abstracts.cdata!:
The audit rates the project outcome as
            moderately satisfactory, with an unlikely sustainability,
            and modest institutional development impacts. Both
            performances by the Bank, and Borrower are assessed
            unsatisfactory, given the poor quality at entry, conducive
            to critical failures in the appraisal of management
            practices, and, the neglect in establishing an independent
            research advisory committee to oversee the project's
            science agenda, respectively. The lessons learned raise two
            major issues: a) how to ensure a balanced scientific
            research, and pro-active planning for resource management,
            and, b) how to achieve sustainable management of
            trans-boundary resources, given differing riparian
            interests, and incentives to participate. The balance
            between research, and planning appears to be primarily
            determined by the terms of reference of the project manager,
            and to a lesser extent, by the effectiveness of the steering
            committee. While undoubtedly, the project's
            science-bias caused a lack of focus on the planning, and
            resource management, a more generalist scientific approach
            would have improved the Lake's management plans, and, a
            well designed operational set-up would have achieved
            relevant objectives, with a greater inclusive, and riparian
            approach to a balanced biodiversity conservation. Bank
            efforts should facilitate regional institutions, and plan
            extensive consultations to coordinate riparian efforts,
            through free-standing projects to better support
            cross-boundary resource conservation, with objective
            management, and technical reviews, and carefully structured partnerships.
